div.p:
Alderman: Since the guilds became identified with the corporation or ruling municipal body: A magistrate in English and Irish cities and boroughs, next in dignity to the mayor; properly, as in London, the chief officer of a ward.
Oxford English Dictionary
1807 - 1825: A city position in Pensacola FL, Savannah GA, New Orleans LA, Annapolis MD and St. Louis MO.
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

Assembly: A gathering of persons for the purpose of deliberation and decision; a deliberative body, a legislative council.
Assembly or General Assembly: the name given to the lower house in New Jersey and New York.
Oxford English Dictionary
1788 - 1825: New Jersey, New York
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County

Assessor:
a. One who sits as assistant or adviser to a judge or magistrate; esp. a skilled assistant competent to advise on technical points of law, commercial usage, navigation, etc.
b. One who assesses taxes.
c. One who officially estimates the value of property or income for purposes of taxation.
Oxford English Dictionary
1801 - 1825: Delaware, Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island
Office Scope: County / City / Hundred / District
Role Scope: County / Hundred / Ward / District

Assistant Assessor: One who assists the Assessor. See Assessor
1807 - 1822: Philadelphia, Northern Liberties and Penn, Pennsylvania
Office Scope: City / Township
Role Scope: Township / Ward

Attorney-General: a legal officer of the state empowered to act in all cases in which the state is a party. In England, Isle of Man, many Commonwealth countries, and in the United States, (formerly also in Ireland), the title of the first ministerial law-officer of the government, also of his or her Majesty's attorney in the duchy of Lancaster
Oxford English Dictionary
1787-1825: Georgia, New Jersey, North Carolina, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State / District (Georgia only)

Auditor: An official whose duty it is to receive and examine accounts of money in the hands of others, who verifies them by reference to vouchers, and has power to disallow improper charges.
Oxford English Dictionary
1804-1825: Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / County

Bank Director: Head position at the Bank of Pennsylvania, the Bank of Philadelphia and the Bank of South Carolina.
1800-1816: Pennsylvania, South Carolina
Office Scope: State / City
Role Scope: State / City

Assistant Alderman: Since the guilds became identified with the corporation or ruling municipal body: Assitant to the alderman position.
Oxford English Dictionary
1824: A city position in Albany, NY.
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: Ward

Brigade Inspector: A military position that was publically voted on in 19th Century Pennsylvania.
1807 - 1821: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / County

Brigadier-General: A military officer in command of a brigade; the status ranks between a major-general and a colonel, but is only local or temporary, being generally held by the senior colonel of the regiments or battalions brigaded together.
Oxford English Dictionary
1803 - 1821: Georgia, Pennsylvania, Virginia
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / County

Circuit Court:
(a) Federal courts intermediate in authority between the District Courts and the Supreme Court of the U. S.
(b) various State Courts so-called for different reasons in particular States
Oxford English Dictionary
1809 - 1823: Georgia, Ohio
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

City Council: The local administrative body of a corporate city
Oxford English Dictionary
1801 - 1825: Baltimore, MD; Charleston, SC
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

Clerk: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of any department, court, corporation, or society, and superintends the general conduct of its business
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1822: Georgia, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, New Jersey, New York
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / County

auth:office.name: Court of the Common Pleas President

div.p:
Court of the Common Pleas President: The head of one of three circuits of courts as designated by the Ohio Constitution of 1802.
1810: Ohio
Office Scope: District
Role Scope: State

Clerk of the Assembly: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Assembly
1794 - 1822: New Jersey, New York
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Clerk of the Court: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Court
1819 - 1825: Arkansas, Georgia, Indiana, Ohio, South Carolina
Office Scope: County / District (South Carolina only)
Role Scope: County / District (South Carolina only)

auth:office.name: Clerk of the House of Delegates

div.p:
Clerk of the House of Delegates: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the House of Delegates
1798 - 1816: Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

auth:office.name: Clerk of the House of Representatives

div.p:
The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the House of Representatives
1787 - 1825: Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont
Office Scope: State / Territory (Missouri)
Role Scope: State / Territory (Missouri)

auth:office.name: Assistant Clerk of the House of Representatives

div.p:
The assistant officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the House of Representatives
1807 - 1809: Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Inferior Court
1809 - 1819: Georgia, Rhode Island
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Clerk of the Market: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Market
1803 - 1818: New Castle, DE; Savannah, GA, Newport, RI
Office Scope: Town / City (Savannah)
Role Scope: Town / City (Savannah)

Clerk of the Senate: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Senate
1800 - 1824: Kentucky, Massachusetts, Missouri, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Assistant Clerk of the Senate: The assistant officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Senate
1809 - 1811: Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Clerk of the Superior Court: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Superior Court
1787 - 1811: Georgia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Clerk of the Supreme Court: The officer who has charge of the records, correspondence, and accounts of the Supreme Court
1802 - 1817: New Jersey
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Please see U.S. House of Representatives or U.S. Senate
Office Scope:
Role Scope:

Colonel: An officer in the U.S. Air Force or Marine Corps, ranking next below a brigadier general.
Oxford English Dictionary
1807: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Commissioner: A member of a permanently constituted commission or government board
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1825: Delaware, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County / Town(ship) (Delaware) / District
Role Scope: County / Town(ship) (Delaware) / District
Scope Note: In most of Pennyslvania, this is a County position, but due to the minor civil divisions around Philadelphia, it is also a position for the township of Northern Liberties and the District of Spring Garden.

Common Council: The administrative body of a corporate town or city; a town or city council.
In Philadelphia the local authority consisted of the Select Council and Common Council, called together the Councils
Oxford English Dictionary
1799 - 1822: Annapolis, MD; Alexandria, VA; Norfolk, VA; Richmond, VA
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City / Ward

Comptroller/Controller: One who keeps a counter-roll so as to check a treasurer or person in charge of accounts.
Oxford English Dictionary
1809 - 1823: Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Constable: The chief officer of the court or administration
Oxford English Dictionary
1803 - 1824: Missouri, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island
Office Scope: County / City / Town(ship) / Borough
Role Scope: County / City / Town(ship) / Borough

Convention: In Law, A body constituted by statute to represent the people in their primary relations, and in some sense outside of the constitution, as e.g. for the framing or amending of the constitution itself (Constitutional Convention). In this sense, applied to a body meeting under authority of Congress to frame a constitution for a new state, or convened by a state legislature, in the manner prescribed by law, to revise the constitution of the state.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1824: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia
Office Scope: State / Territory
Role Scope: State / County / District / City

Convention: An assembly of delegates or representatives for some special or occasional purpose.
Oxford English Dictionary
1801 - 1823: New York, Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / Ward

Convention President: Presiding officer of a Constitutional Convention
1811 - 1820: Louisiana, Missouri
Office Scope: Territory
Role Scope: Territory

Convention Secretary: The Secretary of a Constitutional Convention
1820: Missouri
Office Scope: Territory
Role Scope: Territory

Coroner: An officer of a county, district or municipality (formally also of the royal household), originally charged with maintaining the rights of the private property of the crown; in modern times his chief function is to hold inquests on the bodies of those supposed to have died by violence or accident.
-Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1824: Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Mississippi, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennyslvania
Office Scope: County / District (some combined counties within Ohio and Pennsylvania)
Role Scope: County / District (some combined counties within Ohio and Pennsylvania)

Upper house of the state legislature or assistant to the Governor.
Please also see State Senate or Council of Assistants Council: An assembly called together for any purpose; a convocation or congregation.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1820: Delaware, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Vermont
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / County

A position in the Pennsylvania Militia, which was organized by counties.
1800: Northumberland County, PA
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

The upper body of the Connecticut General Assembly dating back to 1698. It had twelve positions that were elected statewide. It continued until the implementation of the Connecticut Constitution in 1818. Please also see State Senate
1790 - 1818: Connecticut
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Electoral Assembly for State Senate: A representative body that elects members to the Maryland State Senate.
1796 - 1821: Maryland
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / City

An elected judicial position in Virginia.
1811 - 1824: Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Director: One who or that which directs, rules, or guides; a guide, a conductor; â€˜one that has authority over others; a superintendent
Oxford English Dictionary
1799 - 1803: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Director of the Poor: Head position in the poor house. Known in Ohio and Rhode Island as Overseer of the Poor.
1800 - 1824: Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island
Office Scope: County / Town (Rhode Island)
Role Scope: County / Town (Rhode Island)

The Sergeant at Arms and Doorkeeper, elected by the members, serves as the protocol and chief law enforcement officer and is the principal administrative manager for most support services in a legislature.
1794 - 1824: Kentucky, Missouri, New York
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Elector: A member of the Electoral College chosen by the several States to elect the President and Vice-President.
Oxford English Dictionary

See President of the United States for the votes cast by the Electoral College for President
Historical Note: These elections were vastly different from modern day Presidential elections. The actual Presidential candidates were rarely mentioned on tickets and voters were voting for particular electors who were pledged to a particular candidate. There was sometimes confusion as to who the particular elector was actually pledged to. Prior to the 12th Amendment, electors were pledged to two candidates as there was no distinction made in the Electoral College between President and Vice-President.
1789 - 1824: Alabama, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia
State Breakdown for Election of Members to the Electoral College:
Alabama: Legislature (1820), Popular Vote (1824)
Connecticut: Legislature (1789-1816), Popular Vote (1820, 1824)
Delaware: Popular Vote (1789), Legislature (1796-1824)
Georgia: Legislature (1789, 1792, 1800-1824), Popular Vote (1796)
Illinois: Popular Vote by District
Indiana: Legislature (1816, 1820), Popular Vote by District (1824)
Kentucky: Popular Vote by District
Louisiana: Legislature
Maine: Popular Vote by District
Maryland: Popular Vote (1789, 1792), Popular Vote by District (1796-1824)
Massachusetts: Popular Vote (1789-1796, 1804, 1824), Legislature (1800, 1808, 1816), Popular Vote by District (1812, 1820)
Mississippi: Popular Vote
Missouri: Legislature (1820), Popular Vote by District (1824)
New Hampshire: Popular Vote (1789-1796, 1804-1824), Legislature (1800)
New Jersey: Legislature (1789-1800, 1812), Popular Vote (1804, 1808, 1816-1824)
New York: Legislature
North Carolina: Legislature (1792, 1812), Popular Vote by District (1796-1808), Popular Vote (1816-1824)
Ohio: Popular Vote
Pennsylvania: Popular Vote (1789-1796, 1804-1824), Legislature (1800)
Rhode Island: Legislature (1792, 1796), Popular Vote (1800-1824)
South Carolina: Legislature
Tennessee: Popular Vote by District
Vermont: Legislature
Virginia: Popular Vote by District (1789-1796), Popular Vote (1800-1824)
Office Scope: Federal
Role Scope: State / District

Council: A body of men chosen or designated as permanent advisers on matters of state, esp. to advise and assist a sovereign or ruler in the administration of the government.
Oxford English Dictionary
1799 - 1817: Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

An official appointed to govern a province, country, town, etc. Now used as the official title of the representative of the Crown in a British colony or dependency; also of the executive head of each of the United States.
-Oxford English Dictionary
Historical Note: In many states, primarily in the South, this was a position elected by the State Legislature rather than by popular vote.
1787-1824: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

In Crown colonies and dependencies of Great Britain, a body assisting the governor in an executive or legislative capacity, or in both. This survives in some of the United States, as Massachusetts and Maine, in the advisory body called the Governor's Council.
Oxford English Dictionary
1790 - 1824: Maine, Maryland, New Hampshire
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State / County (New Hampshire) / Town (New Hampshire)

House of Commons: the lower house of the North Carolina State legislature. Derived from the lower house of the British Parliment.
1790 - 1825: North Carolina
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / Town / Borough

House of Delegates: the lower house of the General Assembly in Maryland and Virginia.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1825: Maryland, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / City / Borough

House of Representatives: the lower or popular house of the United States Congress or of a State legislature. The name of the lower house in all states prior to 1825 except for Maryland and Virginia, House of Delegates, New Jersey and New York Assembly and North Carolina House of Commons.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1825: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / District / Town(ship) / Parish

One who inspects or looks carefully at or into; an overseer, a superintendent; spec. an officer appointed to examine into, and supervise or report upon, the working of some department or institution in which numerous persons are employed, or the due observance of certain laws and regulations, as inspector of elections.
Oxford English Dictionary
1801 - 1824: Delaware, Pennsylvania
Office Scope: City / Township / Borough / Hundred (Delaware)
Role Scope: Township / Borough / Ward / Hundred (Delaware)

One who has the charge, direction, or superintendence of a department of public business, the affairs of a town or province.
Oxford English Dictionary
1788 - 1824: Charlesoton, SC
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

A public officer appointed to administer the law; one who has authority to hear and try causes in a court of justice.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1819: Georgia, Indiana, North Carolina, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee
Office Scope: State / Territory / County
Role Scope: State / Territory / District / County

Legislative Council: The name of the ruling legislative body of several U.S. territories before they reached statehood. Also the name of the upper body in the New Jersey legislature prior to 1844 State Senate.
1788 - 1825: Arkansas, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri, New Jersey
Office Scope: State / Territory
Role Scope: Territory / District / County

Lieutenant Governor: the deputy-governor of a state with certain independent duties and the right of succession to the governorship, in case of its becoming vacant
Oxford English Dictionary
1788 - 1824: Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New York, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Vermont
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Major: An officer in the army ranking below a lieutenant-colonel and above a captain
Oxford English Dictionary
1807: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Mayor: The head or chief officer of the municipal government of a city, borough, etc., now usually elected by local councillors or citizens
Oxford English Dictionary
1801 - 1824: New Orleans, LA; Annapolis, MD; Boston, MA; St. Louis, MO; Philadelphia, PA
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

Electoral Assembly for Mayor: A representative body that elects the Mayor of Baltimore, Maryland. There was no direct election of the Mayor of Baltimore until 1833.
1802 - 1824: Baltimore, MD
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

Moderator: A person chosen or appointed to preside over a meeting or assembly and conduct its business; a presiding officer or president, esp. (U.S.) one elected to oversee a town meeting
1806 - 1815: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island Oxford English Dictionary
Office Scope: Town
Role Scope: Town
President

The (usually elected) head of a republican state, typically functioning as both head of state and head of government; Frequently prefixed to the surname of the holder of office.
-Oxford English Dictionary
1789 - 1792: The United States of America
Office Scope: Federal
Role Scope: State
These are the results in the Electoral College. For the popular vote, please see the Electoral Collegeelections.

Printer of documents for a government.
1798 - 1824: Kentucky, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Receiver of Tax Returns: A publically elected position in Georgia.
1819: Georgia
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Recorder: Formerly, a certain magistrate or judge having criminal and civil jurisdiction in a city or borough.
Oxford English Dictionary
1812 - 1822: Indiana, Louisiana, Maryland
Office Scope: County / City
Role Scope: County / City

Registrar: a local official responsible for maintaining an index of births, marriages, and deaths in the area under his authority.
Oxford English Dictionary
1793: Georgia
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Registrar of Deeds: a local official responsible for maintaining an index of deeds
1794 - 1821: Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, South Carolina
Office Scope: County / District (South Carolina)
Role Scope: County / District (South Carolina)

Registrar of Wills: a local official responsible for maintaining an index of wills
1803: Maryland
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Road Commission: The public division in charge of maintaining the roads.
1787 - 1813: Delaware, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia
Office Scope: County / Hundred (Delaware)
Role Scope: County / Hundred (Delaware)

Secretary of State: In the official designations of certain ministers presiding over executive departments of state.
Oxford English Dictionary
1798 - 1824: Connecticut, Georgia, Kentucky, Maine, Massachusetts, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Secretary of the Legislative Council: Executive officer in the Legislative Council.
1813: New Jersey
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Secretary of the Senate: Executive officer in the State Senate.
1819 - 1825: Kentucky, Georgia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

The Select and Common Councils made up part of the Philadelphia City government. They were responsible for appointments within the City government.
1800 - 1824: Philadelphia, PA
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City

Senate President: Presiding officer in the State Senate
1804 - 1825: Georgia, Maine, Massachusetts, New York, South Carolina
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Sergeant at Arms: An officer who is charged with the duty of enforcing the commands of the House.
Oxford English Dictionary
1794 - 1824: Kentucky, New York, Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Sheriff: executes civil and criminal process throughout the county, has charge of the jail and prisoners, attends courts and keeps the peace.
Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1824: Alabama, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Mississippi, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina
Office Scope: County / City / District (Pennsylvania, South Carolina)
Role Scope: County / City / District (Pennsylvania, South Carolina)

Solicitor General: a law-officer, who takes the part of the state or crown in suits affecting the public interest.
1816 - 1821: Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Speaker of the Assembly: Presiding officer in the Assembly.
1794 - 1824: New Jersey, New York
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Speaker of the House: Presiding officer in the House of Representatives.
1787 - 1825: Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

auth:office.name: Speaker of the House Pro Tempore

div.p:
Speaker of the House Pro Tempore: Temporary presiding officer in the House of Representatives.
1808 - 1821: Kentucky
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Speaker of the Senate: Presiding officer in the State Senate.
1796 - 1825: Delaware, Kentucky, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

auth:office.name: Speaker of the Senate Pro Tempore

div.p:
Speaker of the Senate Pro Tempore: Temporary presiding officer in the State Senate.
1804 - 1820: Kentucky
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

The upper house of the State Legislature.
Please see also Council or Council of Assistants.
1787 - 1825: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State (Connecticut) / County / District / City / Parish (Lousiana, South Carolina)

Justice of the Superior Court: Judge on the higher court in those states that have multiple level courts (usually designated as Superior and Inferior).
1807 - 1819: North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Supervisor: In some of the United States, An elected officer, or one of a board of such officers, charged with the administration of a township.
Oxford English Dictionary
1794 - 1820: New York, Ohio
Office Scope: County / City / Town
Role Scope: County / City / Town / Ward

Surveyor: As a title of officials in various departments, offices, or works; e.g. one who superintends the construction of a building, the administration of an office or department, the collection of taxes, the keeping of a structure in good order or repair.
Oxford English Dictionary
1793 - 1823: Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee
Office Scope: State / County
Role Scope: State / District / County

Tax Collector: In early America, a publically elected official charged with collecting the taxes.
1809 - 1825: Georgia
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Tax Receiver: A publically elected official in charge of receiving the taxes.
1824 - 1825: Georgia
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

Solicitor: a law-officer, who takes the part of the state or crown in suits affecting the public interest.
1815: North Carolina
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: District

auth:office.name: President of the Supreme Executive Council

div.p:
President of the Supreme Executive Council: The leader of the Supreme Executive Council. In Pennsylvania, prior to the 1790 Constitution, the Executive Branch consisted of the Supreme Executive Council, which was run by the President. It was the equivalent of a Governor.
1789: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

auth:office.name: Vice President of the Supreme Executive Council

div.p:
Vice President of the Supreme Executive Council: The leader of the Supreme Executive Council. In Pennsylvania, prior to the 1790 Constitution, the Executive Branch consisted of the Supreme Executive Council, of which the Vice President was second in command.. It was the equivalent of a Lieutenant Governor.
1789: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Assistant: A city position in New York.
1789 - 1804: Albany
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City / Ward

Supreme Executive Council: In Pennsylvania, prior to the 1790 Constitution, the Executive Branch consisted of the Supreme Executive Council, which was run by the President.
1787 - 1789: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: County / City

Town Clerk: The clerk or secretary to the corporation of a town, who has charge of the records, correspondence, and legal business, the conduct of municipal elections, etc.
Oxford English Dictionary
1803 - 1824: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island
Office Scope: Town(ship) / Borough (Pennsylvania)
Role Scope: Town(ship) / Borough (Pennsylvania)

Town-Council: the elective deliberative and administrative body of a town
Oxford English Dictionary
1809 - 1818: Pennsylvania, Rhode Island
Office Scope: Town / Borough (Pennsylvania)
Role Scope: Town / Borough (Pennsylvania)

One who has officially the charge of treasure; originally, a person entrusted with the receipt, care, and disbursement of the revenues of a king, noble, or other dignitary, of a state, city, or church; now, one who is responsible for the funds of a public body, or of any corporation, association, society, or club.
-Oxford English Dictionary
1787 - 1826: Connecticut, Georgia, Kentucky, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennyslvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Vermont, Virginia
Office Scope: State / County / City / Town(ship)
Role Scope: State / County / District / City / Town(ship)

A Pennsylvanian office referring to the University.
1810 - 1823: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

House of Representatives: the lower or popular house of the United States Congress
1788 - 1826: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia
Office Scope: Federal
Role Scope: District / State
Historical Note: The following states had a Role Scope of State at various times because they only had one member in the U.S. House of Representatives:
Alabama (1819, 1821)
Delaware (1789 - 1810, 1822, 1824)
Illinois (1818 - 1824)
Indiana (1816 - 1820)
Louisiana (1812 - 1820)
Mississippi (1817 - 1824)
Missouri (1820 - 1824)
Ohio (1803)
Rhode Island (1790)
Tennessee (1796 - 1801)
Historical Note: The following states had a Role Scope of State at various times because they elected their members at-large and each Representative served the entire state instead of a specific district:
Connecticut (1790 - 1824)
Delaware (1812 - 1822)
Georgia (1789 - 1824)
New Hampshire (1790 - 1824)
New Jersey (1789 - 1796, 1800 - 1810, 1814 - 1824)
Pennsylvania (1788, 1792)
Rhode Island (1792 - 1825)
Tennessee (1803)
Vermont (1812 - 1818, 1822)

U.S. Senate: the upper house of the United States Congress.
1788 - 1825: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia
Office Scope: Federal
Role Scope: State
Historical Note: Prior to the passage of the 17th Amendment in 1913, all United States Senators were elected by state legislatures rather than by popular vote.

Vice-President of the United States: The second highest position in the United States government. Not directly elected by popular vote.
1824: Virginia
Office Scope: Federal
Role Scope: State

The second highest executive officer in the Legislative Council.
1801 - 1813: New Jersey
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

Warden: The officer who presides at ward-meetings or elections.
1787 - 1824: Philadelphia, PA; Charleston, SC
Office Scope: City
Role Scope: City / Ward

A member of the commission that runs the poor house.
1807: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

State Supreme Court Judge: A judge on the highest court in a state.
1791 - 1824: Illinois, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont
Office Scope: State
Role Scope: State

A magistrate or member of the governing body of a town. Used as an official title (with varying signification) in certain English boroughs before the Municipal Reform Act of 1835.
-Oxford English Dictionary
1810: Pennsylvania
Office Scope: Borough
Role Scope: Borough

Justice of the Peace: an inferior magistrate appointed to preserve the peace in a county, town, or other district, and discharge other local magisterial functions.
Oxford English Dictionary
1804 - 1824: Ohio
Office Scope: Township
Role Scope: Township

Levy Court Commissioner: The levy court in Delaware originated during the Dutch period (1655 - 1664) as a body for tax control. Through the history of the First State, the Levy Court took many forms with varying degrees of power and authority. The Levy Court serves the same function as a county council and consists of seven elected commissioners. One commissioner is elected from each of the six Levy Court districts and one commissioner is elected at large. These commissioners represent the governing body of the county and hold weekly business and committee meetings which are open to the public.
definition from The Natural Resources Conservation Service: http://www.de.nrcs.usda.gov/partnerships/rcd/what_is_levy_court.html
1794 - 1824: Delaware
Office Scope: County
Role Scope: County

"The upper branch of the legislature in the colonies was called the council, and consisted usually of twelve members, called assistants or members of the governor's council. Except in Connecticut and Rhode Island, the members of the council were either appointed by the governor or by the lower house." A History of the United States. William Coligny Doub. Pages 225-226.
"The latter body (assistants), formerly called the council, was now with the two executive officers, termed the upper house, and afterwards received the name of Senate." History of the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations Vol II. Samuel Green Arnold. Page 555.
"In 1798 the new state's first code of laws changed the nomenclature of Rhode Island government in several areas. From that point onward the upper house became known as the senate, and the lower chamber as the House of Representatives. The title of the deputy governor became lieutenant governor." The Rhode Island State Constitution: A Reference Guide. Patrick T. Conley, Robert G. Flanders. Page 212.
Please also see State Senate or Council of Assistants

Council of Appointment: A branch of the New York state government from 1777 to 1822. It was charged with appointing all officers of the state that had not otherwise been listed in the New York Constitution of 1777 as being appointed or elected in a specific way. This included the Secretary of State, Comptroller, Attorney General, Surveyor General, justice of the New York Supreme Court, sheriffs, judges, district attorneys, mayors and all military officers. The Council was abolished by the New York Constitution of 1821 and ceased to exist by the end of 1822.
"That all officers, other than those who, by this constitution, are directed to be otherwise appointed, shall be appointed in the manner following, to wit: The assembly shall, once in every year, openly nominate and appoint one of the senators from each great district, which senators shall form a council for the appointment of the said officers, of which the governor for the time being, or the lieutenant-governor, or the president of the senate, when they shall respectively administer the government, shall be president and have a casting voice, but no other vote; and with the advice and consent of the said council, shall appoint all the said officers; and that a majority of the said council be a quorum. And further, the said senators shall not be eligible to the said council for two years successively." Constitution of New York. April 20, 1777. Article XXIII.
